description: From Middle English sted, stede (noun) and steden (verb), from Old English stede, from Proto-Germanic *stadiz, from Proto-Indo-European *st√©h‚ÇÇtis. Cognate with German Stadt, Statt and St√§tte, Gothic êçÉêçÑêå∞êå∏êçÉ (sta√æs, ‚Äúplace‚Äù), Danish and Swedish stad, Norwegian Bokm√•l sted, Scots steid, Dutch stad, Yiddish ◊©◊ò◊ê÷∏◊ò‚Äé (shtot). See the doublet stasis.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A place, or spot, in general. [10th‚Äì16th c.]
(obsolete) A place where a person normally rests; a seat. [10th‚Äì18th c.]
examples: There now the hart, fearlesse of greyhound, feeds, / And loving pelican in safety breeds; / There shrieking satyres fill the people's emptie steads.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) An inhabited place; a settlement, city, town etc. [13th‚Äì16th c.]
(obsolete) An estate, a property with its grounds; a farm; a homestead. [14th‚Äì19th c.]
examples: But of course I could not do this by myself, so I took a Hottentot‚Äîa very clever man when he was not drunk‚Äîwho lived on the stead, into my confidence.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) The frame on which a bed is laid; a bedstead. [15th‚Äì19th c.]
examples: The genial bed / Sallow the feet, the borders, and the stead.

entries.meaning: (in phrases, now literary) The position or function (of someone or something), as taken on by a successor. [from 15th c.]
examples: His nurse had told him all about changelings, and how the little people would always try to steal a beautiful human child out of its cradle and put in its stead one of their own ailing, puking brats  [‚Ä¶]

entries.meaning: (figurative) An emotional or circumstantial "place" having specified advantages, qualities etc. (now only in phrases). [from 15th c.]
examples: Though small and delicate-looking, she gave an impression of intense earnestness and latent toughness, qualities that stood her in good stead when she dared to challenge the most intrusive communist society in eastern Europe.

verbs.description: stead (third-person singular simple present steads, present participle steading, simple past and past participle steaded)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To help, support, benefit or assist; to be helpful.
(obsolete) To fill the stead or place of something.
(Singapore, colloquial) One's partner in a romantic relationship.
